What am I missing here? How is this in ANY WAY a concept for an interesting movie? It's unquestionably the most boring and anticlimactic plot I've ever heard. The camera work is kind of impressive, but pulling back or panning upwards once in a while can't save you from having the dumbest and most uninteresting story ever written. There was NO indication other than his final word that the sled ever held ANY emotional significance to Kane. A sled isn't really the kind of thing you would be thinking of on your deathbed, anyways. I know it's supposed to be a metaphor for a lost childhood, but you can deliver the same message in the form of a story that's actually COMPELLING.

Controversial opinion: I don't think Citizen Kane is as fantastic now as it was when it was released. It used very obvious literary devices and doesn't leave much open for interpretation from the viewer. The "moral of the story" is so evident, straightforward, and echoed among so many other films and books that I have a hard time finding it compelling. That being said, for it being released when it was, it was very revolutionary, but as a plot I just don't think there's that much substance there.

Film criticism isn't meant to be what it sounds like. It is not nitpicking specific details to find and objective "Score". It is meant to be a more professional look into an art form that is consumed by many but understood by few. And of course give interpertations of the films themes, both intended and unintended.
This video is not about film criticism, it is a history lecture about a movie.

The idea of the sled is so great because symbolically, it's obviously a link to his old childhood memories, his only real happy memories until he was taken from his home and pushed into a world of business, money, and power. The sled in and of itself, I think, functions great as the literal "Rosebud." If Rosebud were a person, or a place, or even a specific day, it would be too sappy and probably too predictable. The sled is so great because we see a great shot of it after Kane is taken from his home, and the snow builds up on, signaling the passage of time, the burying of his childhood, and of course intimate screen time with the actual sled. It's unpredictable, yet when we get the twist, it clicks immediately. It also shows how little things really do impress upon our subconscious. Bernstein gives the little speech to Thompson about the woman he saw on the ferry for a second. She never noticed him, yet a month never went by when he didn't think of her. The sled is sort of the same way.

Kane is good as an assemblage of techniques, but even then, a film like Intolerance utilised many of the same techniques decades prior and is infinitely more sophisticated.

I recently studied this film for Arts & Literature and what really struck me about it is the mystery of it all. In the very beginning, when the camera is panning up along the fence, the chain link is in focus and the background is blurry, giving the viewer hints that Kane's life story is going to be a bit fuzzy and that his true self is going to be concealed in some way. Then, the story of his life is told through others, each having their own biases and perspectives on both life and Kane himself. Therefore, we cannot fully trust what they say about him, especially considering how most of them had some kind of falling-out with Kane. I thought it was fascinating how the film took (or, perhaps, helped to form) the concept of the unreliable narrator and translated it into four (five, if you count the butler's brief contribution) unreliable narrators. Because we never see Kane's life through an unbiased narrator or even Kane himself, we as viewers cannot completely discern what is fact and what is exaggeration. Therefore, Kane's real life remains something of a mystery.

At the end of the day, I can appreciate the technical details, but I watch movies for entertainment. Citizen Kane fails abysmally at this. The pacing leaves me bored for large portions, and the dialog is so incredibly formulaic and "scripty." It kind of coasts from scene to scene, caring more about set pieces of story information and less about interest or context. I realize that some of these things are because this movie pioneered what is now the cliche, but from my perspective that doesn't mean I'm enjoying the viewing.

Man, the sled is my favorite part of the film....it is very profound to me! I mean, the film is so literary, I guess that's what makes me feel differently about rosebud.... There is this cave of what is considered classical and medieval wealth for many cultures (precious materials, art, objects with intrinsic value not just representative value) maintained in a massive castle like estate, property based medieval/modern wealth in a European centric, which is all acquired and maintained through the very modern we lath gaining structure of capitalism via industrialization and modernization and business which blatantly intercedes politics. None of these systems recognize rosebud as having any value, intrinsic or representative: its used as fuel (especially noteworthy considering in industrial/capital overtones) Kane sought all the glories known to western European societies, yes Rosebud was his innocent childhood, but it was also his father, his mother, the home he grew up in outside of those realms of wealth, and when they all coalesced onto his life, his mother inheriting land with precious resources to be used for industry, a business transaction, it destroyed his family. I mean, he could think of Rosebud, this modern, gleamy factory-ish produced sleigh (I am assuming) was a death knoll for his capacity to fully experience life and know love. It may not have been a longing for rosebud in his quote, but the summation of forces and societal structures that impeded his life. His mother wanted him to be stable, which meant money, education, etc, he could always have a rosebud, have what he needed, wanted. but I think he came to understand none of that provided him with stability or need-satisfaction of any serious quality. Rosebud in the fire can be a damnation of modern society and the unseen powers at play, peoples doomed ideas of what will constitute a full life; or the former, the question of when wealth and value of familial and human ties will be fundamentally appreciated bu human societies (cant speak for pre-society or traditional human communities) as as valuable as everything in that cave and the mansion and land its contained in, the businesses that built it, or perhaps even more. Will everyone's Rosebud's just be tossed in the fire?

I know film snobs will disagree, but Citizen Kan is NOT the greatest movie of all time. I'm so tired of hearing this cliche. There are so many other greater movies out there. First and foremost, it has no rewatchable value. See it once, no need to see it again. (event though I've seen it 5 times for school and such) It's long, plodding, unrelateable, and worst of all: Boring. The WRH connection was what made this movie famous. Even though there are new techniques in cinematography, lighting, etc. it's just not as great as it is. They always claim that you have to watch it multiple times to 'really' understand what is going on, or notice subtle things. But if you constantly have to explain things, you're telling not showing, and that's one of the worst things to do in story writing.  I could go on forever but I won't. I hate this movie. And I know some of you will blow a gasket. But I don't care.

I was hoping for a more intellectually stimulating and thought-provoking critique, honestly. Preferably one capable of inspiring discussion in the comments section. This video felt more like a short history lesson on Citizen Kane and, to a lesser extent, Orson Welles (with a brief meditation on “Great movie” lists) than actual criticism. I think the video would have fit comfortably under the “Crash Course Film History” header, but that shouldn’t really be the case if “Crash Course Film Criticism” is going to fly its own banner.
Also, Aranda’s opinion of the film seems too much on display, I think. See 7:55: “But a lot of the time what makes our favorite movies so memorable is just a well-told story. And if you think about it, Citizen Kane doesn’t really have a mind-blowing plot. It’s a straightforward tale . . . and the dialogue is all pretty crisp and generic.” And see also 8:35: “Honestly, the fact that it’s his childhood sled isn’t the most profound or surprising twist out there.” It is profound in that its apparent mundanity belies it’s importance as an artifact of Kane’s lost childhood (the sled’s name being a symbol as well), that if he had been able to recognize and accept his mother’s decision to entrust him to a guardian as an act of love, he might have gone on to lead a more fulfilling life. For a film that you could have devoted an entire season to analyzing in close detail from differing critical perspectives, regardless of how dull you would find such a task, I don’t think the 10 minutes it was given here were a fair, or even adequate, shake.

One of the ways something or someone is considered great. Babe Ruth hit more homer us in 1921 than any other team in professional baseball. Not only was he better than anyone at the time, he was more than twice as good as the next person in his field. CITIZEN KANE shares those aspects. It was the first film where the director had complete control of a major film, he even controlled the thinking of it’s star. The camerawork, the story’s form, the visual metaphors were decades ahead of it’s time. It made the director more important than anyone else in the film.

I'm sorry, but they got the story of Orson Welles War of the Worlds wrong. Anyone who listened from the start knew it was an adaptation of H.G. Wells fictional novel. The introduction to the play clearly stated it was drama, and not real. There were also several reminders about it being fiction, at several points later in the broadcast. So Crash Course got it wrong in showing people panicked when listening to it from the start.

I know this is all nitpicking, but for a series of videos that are supposed to be educational, it is important to get it right.

I hope that, somewhere along the way, we connect concepts from Crash Course Literature (e.g, the importance of themes) to this series. It took me a while to realize how concepts from literature class applied to anything but literature class, but once I did, I could better appreciate both literature class and the pop culture I consumed. It would be great if Crash Course could help others do the same.
